entry.title: Playing with ColBERTV2 Embeddings and Retrieval
entry.content: There are a lot of embedding models out there for LLMs. ColbertV2 is a neat one. Here are some thoughts and code examples.

entry.title: The first detailed description of living with esophageal cancer - John Casaubon’s 1690 diary
entry.content: John Casaubon was an English surgeon in the late 1600s who developed an esophageal tumor in late 1690 and wrote about it in his diary before dying in January of 1691. It's harrowing, enlightening, and strangely beautiful. This blog post is the only place in the world you can read the full transcription of the diary entry.

entry.title: Writing clinical notes using AI - a practical experience
entry.content: With Claude 3 Opus (a newish ChatGPT4 competitor) as my copilot, I wrote a pretty darn good SOAP note for an (invented yet realistic) new consult visit. It took a little massaging to get it right, but boy howdy, it did a great job. Here are the prompts and outputs. This stuff has serious potential for streamlining the boring and tedious parts of the job.

entry.title: Drugs we can’t get: S1
entry.content: There are a number of interesting drugs used in the global market that, for one reason or another, do not have FDA approval and are therefore inaccessible in the US, at least outside of clinical trials. S1 is one of them: a better capecitabine.

entry.title: Patient-facing slide decks
entry.content: While I plan on being a physician-scientist forever, I'm not going to work in academia. Over the past few years I've put together very cool infrastructure for giving academic talks (click "talks" above), and it was making me sad that it might not get much use after I leave the university. But then, a ray of sunshine: Why not use my slide deck infrastructure to help in patient conversations?

entry.title: Cold agglutinin disease: fish out of water?
entry.content: Cold agglutinin disease is a fascinating and strange phenomenon, and might happen because we're fish.

entry.title: A timeline of esophageal cancer
entry.content: A couple of friends and I wrote a review article on the history of esophageal cancer. The timeline was so interesting I thought I'd share it here, in a place where it can be easily found and updated.

entry.title: How to add a mirror to a single ZFS disk
entry.content: tl;dr: zpool attach data /dev/disk/by-partlabel/zfs-3a1xx /dev/sdx0. Adjust for your own pool and disks.

entry.title: yt-dlp Nix config
entry.content: yt-dlp is an incredibly useful and customizable tool for downloading online videos from YouTube and elsewhere. Here's my setup (declared in Nix, but easily generalizable).

entry.title: Command-line interfaces for self-hosted music
entry.content: Self-hosting a music server is great. Listening to the tunes via the command line is the way.

entry.title: Pixel 6 DIY screen replacement, with fingerprint reader calibration using Linux
entry.content: The internet, up to now, says you need Windows or MacOS to calibrate the Pixel's fingerprint reader after installing a new screen and digitizer. The internet, up to now, was wrong.

entry.title: password protecting static web pages
entry.content: Static site generators, by and large, do not have support for password protecting individual pages. This post shows a strategy that works for any SSG and does not require server access controls.

entry.title: good machine learning in medicine
entry.content: Because most machine learning in medicine sucks, I thought you might like to see an example of it done well.

entry.title: medical-humanities.org
entry.content: I made a static website as an electronic learning system and forum, with the option for password protected posts and a controlled editing workflow, for free and without a dedicated server. This post has the highlights.

entry.title: I made a thanks page
entry.content: A public, running journal of "hey, thanks" to the folks who make my life better, in big and small ways. Check it out .

entry.title: fix MIME Types to unbreak RSS feeds served by OpenBSD’s httpd(8)
entry.content: I've been getting back into RSS lately. Turns out, my own RSS feed was broken.

entry.title: Upgrading out-of-date OpenBSD installs
entry.content: First of all, don't do how I do. Upgrade your installs regularly. OpenBSD makes it very easy.

entry.title: geocheatcode
entry.content: Here is background and code for a trick I use to get Google to give me best-in-class guesses for latitude and longitude, despite goofy and/or downright bad location searches.

entry.title: Intake presentation on candidal esophagitis
entry.content: candidal esophagitis, achalasia, H Pylori PUD

entry.title: Set Up Enterprise Wifi on Arch Linux
entry.content: Most big institutions have guest and employee wifi networks. Guest wifi is usually fine, fast enough for the basics, but far inferior to employee wifi. On a custom-built OS, such as a fairly minimalist Linux distribution, getting the employee wifi to work can be a beast.

entry.content: Diagnosis is... MDS/MPN/MF NOS. i.e., who knows.

entry.title: R Markdown is my spirit animal
entry.content: Turns out that a better way does exist, and it is R Markdown.
